content:
It is now much improved from the original version.

The interesting part is in the looping to search for seats.
The disappointing part is to calculate the per-seat matches. It is really tedious.
If there is a way to have a different requirement that checks the successful allocation of seat and at the same time less troublesome in counting, this puzzle will be even better.

Approved.
Thanks for all the feedbacks. I removed WIP status, so open for approval/rejection

I feel the statement is too long that killed the fun of solving or attempts to solve this puzzle. 

The logic to solve it may be simple. The comprehension effort could be more than writing the solution. When a new player has a hundred puzzles to browse and to choose from, it is unlikely for him to pick this one.

How to improve it? Trim the word count. Better presentation style. Simplify the requirements to make it easier to explain. Diagrams...

I have not tried to solve the puzzle. 

Maybe the puzzle is a medium one, but the statement makes me feel it's a hard one.

Even if the logic to find a seat and split is kind of logical, it feels cumbersome to explain and thus to read. I like the theme and the general problem of seat finding but the result seems disappointing. Why should I count groupSuccess and personSuccess?

My suggestions:
- use bullet list to explain the different rules of seat finding and group splitting
- avoid flavour text (orangutan, airport...)
- remove any information that is not necessary to solve the pb (tickets can be sold to the same seat)
- consider changing output to %age of happy persons (same pb but easier to describe and perhaps more fun to solve)

Idea for another related puzzle: groups with assigned seats arrive to the cinema. If their seats are taken, they ask the sitting group(s) to find another place. To find another place, a group will sit closest to the center of the room. Calculate how many people have to change place if the first group takes their place in the center. (or how many times people have to change place)

Just one quick word: puzzle is good but the difficulty should be easy instead of medium.
At first I built a super optimized solution but I had an issue with one test and to help me debug I built also a super dumb solution that follows exactly step by step the groups' algorithm.
I was surprised to see that the super dumb solution is by far enough for every tests / validators.
I was really expecting a higher difficulty, harder validators with even bigger cinema maybe ?
This is my 2nd ever puzzle candidate. To avoid getting bad rating after (and if) it is approved, I kindly ask for any feedback, improvement suggestions, etc. in the pending stage.

Thanks for the feedback and for your time to solve this candidate puzzle!

My sample solution also uses the 'dumb' approach. As groups can come in any order, size, place etc, I didn't think the simulation of seat-finding can be really avoided. My intention was not a computational-complexity optimization puzzle, but a simple simulation puzzle. 

Regarding bigger cinema: I don't know what is the maximum for input data size. One test case already involves 187 lines of input, can it be /shall it be increased even?

Regarding difficulty setting: I am a bit afraid to put it under easy, as having to split the groups can be tricky (I use a stack of Group objects in my sample solution, but I can imagine to use some recursion as well.)  I think this puzzle needs a bit more effort than most of the current 'easy' ones, and I want to avoid frustration which I seem to have caused with my other, IMHO easier puzzle. But if other puzzle approvers agree, I shall modify it.

Thanks for the feedback. I edited description with bullet points, deleted unnecessary text, trying to trim the length. Still not too short, but disambiguity is even worse then being long :-(
I did not change the output to %, as this would  mean even more complication to be added to the description (how many digits of %, which rounding method to use, etc.)
Thanks for the feedback. I created a diagram and edited description trying to trim the length. Still not too short, but disambiguity is even worse then being long :-(

The presentation looks better now. 

Will there be cases where the group is bigger than the length of a row? Or from the first booked seat to the end of the row it cannot fit in the whole group?

Also suggest making the URL more obvious than it is now, making it easier to see in the first glance.

In my sample solution handling personSuccess is only  5 extra lines. In the Group object I store both the current and original numPersons. If a (sub)group can sit down at x,y, I only have to  count how many seats are overlapping between (x,y, numPersons) and the original ticket's (row, column, origNumPersons). 2 ifs, 1 for.

URL updated.
The issued tickets shall be always valid (e.g. fitting fully in the row) to limit complexity (although group split method would work here as well). According to constraints:
  1 ≤ numPersons ≤ maxColumn
  0 ≤ column ≤ maxColumn - 1
Now I also added for further clarify:
  column + numPersons ≤ maxColumn
No idea about the max size. But as you think, there might be limitations in place.
